verses.text: This is the book of the generations of Adam. When God created mankind, He made them in the likeness of God.
verses.comment: The mention of the 'book of the generations' introduces a formal genealogy, underlining the historicity and continuity of the human race. The image of being made in God's likeness is foundational for Christian anthropology, linking creation to the Incarnation—when Christ, the new Adam, assumes human nature. See also Romans 5:14.

verses.text: He created them male and female, and blessed them and named them 'Man' when they were created.
verses.comment: 'Male and female' affirms the binary nature of humanity in God's plan, foreshadowing marriage as a sacramental mystery. The shared name 'Man' shows unity, hinting towards the spiritual family in Christ.

verses.text: When Adam had lived 130 years, he fathered a son in his own likeness, according to his image, and named him Seth.
verses.comment: Seth is presented as Adam's true heir, in contrast to Cain. The 'likeness and image' language mirrors God's creation of Adam, signifying the transmission of both life and spiritual heritage.

verses.text: The days of Adam after he fathered Seth were eight hundred years, and he had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: The long lifespan reflects early biblical history before the effects of sin limited human life. The existence of 'other sons and daughters' points to a broader human family, paralleling believers' spiritual kinship in Christ.

verses.text: So all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred thirty years, and then he died.
verses.comment: Adam's death confirms the divine warning that the consequence of sin is mortality. Death enters the world, a theme which is contrasted with Christ bringing life—see Romans 5:17.

verses.text: When Seth had lived one hundred five years, he fathered Enosh.
verses.comment: Enosh's birth marks continued lineage; the people began to call on the name of the Lord in his days, shaping early worship patterns.

verses.text: Seth lived after he fathered Enosh eight hundred seven years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Seth's extended life allows for the proliferation of humanity. The repeated phrase 'other sons and daughters' maintains lineage and points to the inclusive nature of God's saving plan for all.

verses.text: All the days of Seth were nine hundred twelve years, and then he died.
verses.comment: Death is the common denominator, highlighting humanity's need for redemption. The genealogy's rhythm pointedly creates anticipation for an eventual break in the cycle—see the Enoch account later in this chapter.

verses.text: When Enosh had lived ninety years, he fathered Kenan.
verses.comment: The genealogical record keeps moving forward—the continuity of faith, inheritance, and human experience suggests a purposeful divine order.

verses.text: Enosh lived after he fathered Kenan eight hundred fifteen years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Long lifespans serve to underscore the unique conditions of the antediluvian world, yet also stress the ongoing covenantal relationships being formed.

verses.text: All the days of Enosh were nine hundred five years, and then he died.
verses.comment: The regularity of the phrase 'and then he died' reminds us of the gravity of sin. Christ's resurrection ultimately interrupts this pattern.

verses.text: When Kenan had lived seventy years, he fathered Mahalalel.
verses.comment: Another generation. These genealogies have significance in tracing the Messianic line, as seen in Matthew 1:1-16.

verses.text: Kenan lived after he fathered Mahalalel eight hundred forty years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Continuity, blessing, and human flourishing echo the mandate to 'be fruitful and multiply.'

verses.text: All the days of Kenan were nine hundred ten years, and then he died.
verses.comment: The rhythm of life and death still holds. The pattern points ahead to the need for one who will break the curse—Christ.

verses.text: When Mahalalel had lived sixty-five years, he fathered Jared.
verses.comment: The genealogy continues to shape biblical history and foreshadow the coming generations.

verses.text: Mahalalel lived after he fathered Jared eight hundred thirty years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: 'Other sons and daughters' is a refrain signifying the fullness of human family, prefiguring the spiritual family of those united in faith.

verses.text: All the days of Mahalalel were eight hundred ninety-five years, and then he died.
verses.comment: The pattern holds—death for all except those God sets apart for a unique role, as in the case of Enoch.

verses.text: When Jared had lived one hundred sixty-two years, he fathered Enoch.
verses.comment: The genealogy reaches Enoch, a pivotal figure. Enoch is associated with walking intimately with God.

verses.text: Jared lived after he fathered Enoch eight hundred years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Another generation passes, with future hope encapsulated in the coming line.

verses.text: All the days of Jared were nine hundred sixty-two years, and then he died.
verses.comment: Continuing the genealogy allows for tracing promise and fulfillment—leading toward Messianic hope.

verses.text: When Enoch had lived sixty-five years, he fathered Methuselah.
verses.comment: Methuselah becomes famous for his longevity, but Enoch is famous for his spiritual walk.

verses.text: Enoch walked with God after he fathered Methuselah three hundred years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Enoch ‘walking with God’ is more than moral uprightness—it is deep communion, symbolizing spiritual union. This intimacy hints at later doctrines like sanctification and the possibility of deep spiritual transformation. Spiritual perfection in Enoch points ahead to Christ’s sinless life.

verses.text: All the days of Enoch were three hundred sixty-five years.
verses.comment: Enoch's significantly shorter life is noteworthy, hinting at something extraordinary in his story.

verses.text: Enoch walked with God, and he was not, for God took him.
verses.comment: Enoch’s translation into heaven without experiencing death prefigures both the hope of bodily resurrection and Christ’s own ascension. Enoch is a type of Christ and a promise of eternal life to those united with God.

verses.text: When Methuselah had lived one hundred eighty-seven years, he fathered Lamech.
verses.comment: Genealogy moves forward; Methuselah’s age is famous, often interpreted as a sign of divine patience before judgment.

verses.text: Methuselah lived after he fathered Lamech seven hundred eighty-two years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Continuity and abundance are reaffirmed—God's plan unfolds through ordinary family life.

verses.text: All the days of Methuselah were nine hundred sixty-nine years, and then he died.
verses.comment: Methuselah is the longest-lived human recorded in Scripture. His long life is a sign of both mercy and patience before the coming flood.

verses.text: When Lamech had lived one hundred eighty-two years, he fathered a son.
verses.comment: The anticipation builds as the genealogy leads to Noah, a man through whom God will renew the world.

verses.text: He named him Noah and said, 'This one will comfort us concerning our work and the toil of our hands, because of the ground that the Lord has cursed.'
verses.comment: Noah’s naming signifies hope and anticipated deliverance, prefiguring the rest and salvation Christ offers. The theme of comfort links to Christ-Messiah as our ultimate source of rest.

verses.text: Lamech lived after he fathered Noah five hundred ninety-five years, and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: The ongoing family line ensures the continuity of God's promise, showing that His plan encompasses all nations and peoples.

verses.text: All the days of Lamech were seven hundred seventy-seven years, and then he died.
verses.comment: A symbolic number (seven), associated with completion and divine action, foreshadows spiritual fullness to come through God's chosen line.

verses.text: After Noah was five hundred years old, Noah fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.comment: Noah's three sons become progenitors of the human race after the flood, symbolizing the threefold nature of unity amidst diversity in God's family. This prepares the way for the salvation of the world through a remnant people.
